Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2013 02:39PM tallydiver wrote: Moffit was great!!  Dr. Kiluk spent nearly an hour with my mom and even walked us down to RAD to meet with a RAD Onc (Dr. Candace Correa – Super impressive btw) to discuss Intrabeam.  Shands was great, but Moffit was spectacular.  She has decided to go with experience, as Kiluk has performed 2,000 breast surgeries in the last 6 years.  Additionally, he was 2012 Surgeon of the year at Moffit.  Here are details related to the discussion/examination... Age: 64 years Author: KILUK MD, JOHN V Staging Staging: Breast cancer - 06/01/13 Primary Tumor (T) Primary Tumor (T) Clinical: T1b Laterality: right Regional Lymph Nodes (N) Regional Lymph Nodes (N) Clinical: N0 Distant Metastasis (M) Distant Metastasis (M) Clinical: M0 Staging Groups Clinical Stage: IA Prognostic Factors Estrogen receptor and test method (IHC, RT-PCR, other): + Progesterone receptor and test method (IHC, RT-PCR, other): + HER2 status and test method (IHC, FISH, CISH, RT-PCR, other): - Histologic Grade (G) Histologic Grade: Grade I or 1 Additional Descriptors Clinical stage was used in treatment planning: Yes National guidelines were used in treatment planning: NCCN Treatment Summary: . May 2013: Abnormal right breast imaging. 1 cm mass identified 9:00 right breast. Ultrasound guided core biopsy: Invasive ductal cancer, ER positive PR positive HER-2/neu negative. MRI: No additional suspicious lesions. Visit Information Date of Service: 06/20/2013 Visit type: New patient evaluation. Chief Complaint Right breast cancer Interval History Breast: Nipple discharge: None. Gastrointestinal: No nausea, No vomiting, No diarrhea, No abdominal pain. Genitourinary: No dysuria. Hematological/Lymphatics: No bruising tendency. Musculoskeletal: No back pain. Neurologic: Alert and oriented X4, No confusion. All other systems are negative Procedure History Breast biopsy and related procedures (355759010) in 2013 at 64 Years. Gynecologic biopsy (123858013) in 2012 at 62 Years. Family History Breast cancer, female Mother Ovarian cancer - Maternal Cousin Throat cancer – Father How old were you when your first child was born? 21 Did you breastfeed any of your children more than 1 month? Yes Abortus 0 06/20/2013 11:39 BP (systolic) 145 BP (diastolic) 72 Pulse - Clinic 69 BSA (Metric) 2.15 BMI 36 No lymphadenopathy. Cardiovascular: Normal rate, Regular rhythm, Normal peripheral perfusion. Lung: Lungs are clear to auscultation, Respirations are non-labored, Breath sounds are equal, Symmetrical chest wall expansion. Breast: No mass, No tenderness, No discharge. Hematological/Lymphatics: No lymphadenopathy. Extremities: Normal range of motion, No swelling. Results Review Radiology Results Mammogram: Reviewed radiology films, reviewed radiologist's report. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: Reviewed radiology films, reviewed radiologist's report. Documentation reviewed: case discussed with CORREA MD, CANDACE R. Impression and Plan:  This is a 64 year old female with a new diagnosis of right sided breast cancer. Clinically, she is a T1 C., N0, M0, stage I breast cancer. We had an extensive discussion about breast cancer today including treatment options as per NCCN guidelines. We discussed the difference between lumpectomy, mastectomy, mastectomy with reconstruct ion as well as sentinel node biopsy with possible axillary dissection.  Risks and benefits were explained for al l of these procedures. We discussed different types of radiation including intraoperative radiation therapy.  At this time, the patient prefers a needle localized lumpectomy with intraoperative radiation.  Discuss genetic testing in great detail.  The patient testing is pending and she states the results would potentially impact her surgical decision.  I explained that the first course of action would be to schedule surgery or after she gets her genetic results.  I have given the patient reading information about all of these procedures and have answered all of her questions.  I have given her my contact information including email to call anytime or email with questions.  Total time spent with the patient exceeded 60 minutes with over half the time spent with counseling and coordination of care.
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2013 02:43PM tallydiver wrote: BTW, when talking about neural invasion being present, he shrugged is off as an inconsequential item that should not "muddy the waters" as its clinical indication is not significant or meaningful.  I understand that it is a key factor when looking at cancers that are spread via nerves (IE. Prostrate Cancer)  I have spent a lot of time researching the neural invasiveness and have found that it is congruent with Dr. Kiluk's disreguard.
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2013 10:13PM tallydiver wrote: Deanna - Thank you and she does appreciate me...and she listens to me. I am just happy that I found your wonderful little group, which is still helping us during this process.  I am very appreciative of that.  I hope all is well with you and your family. RMlulu, Thank you and I am very pleased with both teams... Spiegel/Lightsey vs Kiluk/Correa   Kiluk's "Moffitt's Physician of the Year in 2011" seemed to be well deserved as he was pleasant, professional and patient.  However, Correa was the closer.  She was so sweet, gentle and comforting complete with prognostic opinions and predictions.  Kiluk was confident, but more reserved.  After 2000 breasts in 6 years, he has seen surprises "15" percent of the time.  Spiegel was very professional and confident as well as caring.  However, 9 months at Shands with 5-7 breasts per week does not compare to Kiluk's resume.  Lightsey was equally impressive and very helpful...similar to Correa, however Correa blew it out of the water.  Perhaps it is because she was so direct and confident. Hi Liz, I am so happy for you.  It sounds like you have got the dragon by the tail now and have beat this.   I am so happy that my mom joined the other day and is now starting to look around.  Her name is Rachelannette, btw.  Now she is wondering about that lumpectomy.  Were you in much pain, post-op?
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2013 09:51AM tallydiver wrote: Hi RMlulu, It is slowly going away.  Now she has the wire feeling in her breast, but she is doing much better. Regarding the last breast note, I have posted it below. The RO decision is next and when we met with the local MO, he was against the idea of a 1 week 2/day treatments that Moffit had offered with Corea.  After calling Corea's nurse, she countered that the Corea would not have reccommended it if she had not thought it would be a good option.  My feeling is that the MO is ultra conservative - He believes that there is not historical data for it to be a good option.   Corea (RO from Moffit) is on the cutting edge and probably the most current regarding treatment.   We are back to thinking that the week in Tampa at Moffit would be best and more convenient.  They have a deal with a local hotel for $15/night.  (For this purpose, I think) Thanks for all your suggestions related to post Rad comfort measures. I hope you have a great week! Kindest Regards, Author: KILUK MD, JOHN V Staging: Breast cancer - 06/01/13 Primary Tumor (T) Primary Tumor (T) Pathologic: T1c Laterality: right Tumor Size cm: 1.3 Regional Lymph Nodes (N) Regional Lymph Nodes (N) Pathologic: pN0 Distant Metastasis (M) Distant Metastasis (M) Pathologic: M0 Staging Groups Pathologic Stage: IA Prognostic Factors Estrogen receptor and test method (IHC, RT-PCR, other): + Progesterone receptor and test method (IHC, RT-PCR, other): + HER2 status and test method (IHC, FISH, CISH, RT-PCR, other): - Histologic Grade (G) Histologic Grade: Grade I or 1 Additional Descriptors Clinical stage was used in treatment planning: Yes National guidelines were used in treatment planning: NCCN Treatment Summary: . July 2013: Status post right lumpectomy with sentinel node biopsy. Pathology: 1.3 cm invasive ductal cancer, grade 1, ER positive PR positive HER-2/neu negative. Negative sentinel node. IORT not performed secondary to proximity the skin. Visit Information Date of Service: 07/19/2013 Visit type: Scheduled follow-up. Chief Complaint Right breast cancer Interval History Narrative Pat ient is wel l since surgery. Denies fevers. Breast: No infection/hematoma, Status post right lumpectomy.. Impression and Plan This is a 64 year old status post righ t lumpectomy with sent i nel node biopsy. We discussed the pathology in great detai l today. At th is time, I am recommending consul t a t i on with both medical oncology and radiat i on oncology. She wil l see medical oncology local l y but she' l l meet with radiat i on oncology here at Moff i t t for potent i a l part i a l breast radiat i on. I wil l see her back in 6 months with mammogram. I have encouraged her to cal l me i f any concerns in the inter im.
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2013 03:41PM tallydiver wrote: Hey Cindy, I hope all is well with you.   I have been researching AIs and noticed you were using Aromasin.  After doing some research, it seems to be the most tolerated and just as effective as the old traditional Arimidex.  There was even positive mention of Femerra.  My mom's doc want to put her on Arimidex.  She is already suffering from the week after effects from the double dose week of RADs.  Your thoughts Kindest Regards, Tallydiver
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2013 11:01AM tallydiver wrote: Hi Cindy Thanks for the words of encouragement and advice.  Yesterday more details emerged, but waiting on a MRI result this morning.  HER- Neg and ER/PR – Pos.  So that is good news.  I pray for more, today.  Hi Gerric, It was ridiculous having to wait for more than 3 weeks for a biopsy.  It was Shands, btw who performed the biopsy and they mentioned  that it was a problem.  At least now, it is moving…so we shall see.  I had read that Dr. Spiguel was very aggressive and she seemed like a really in-tune surgeon.  We shall see what Moffit has to say. Hi Deanna, Great advice on Moffit.  We are to meet with them next Thursday.  I agree with the perineural invasion question.  My research and Shands comments see to discount as an important finding…but we shall see. I agree with you regarding the ages of the surgeons.  Dr. Spiguel is 36 and Kiluk is 38. Here are details of yesterday’s visit as well as an update related to hormone testing… A. Right Breast, core biopsy: - Invasive Ductal Carcinoma of Breast. See Note - Nottingham Histologic Score: 4 (Grade 1/III) (Tubule Formation: 1; Nuclear Pleomorphism: 2; Mitosis: 1) - Tumor Size: 10.5 mm in greatest linear dimension on one core. - Lymphovascular Involvement: Not Identified - Perineural Invasion: Present - Focal Ductal Carcinoma in-situ (DCIS) of breast (<1mm), cribiform type, low nuclear grade, without necrosis. - Rare microcalcifications are associated with invasive carcinoma. Note: Immunohistochemistry for SMMHC demonstrates loss of a SMMHC(+) myoepithelial cell layer in the invasive component, supporting the diagnosis. Additional studies for ER, PR, and Her2/Neu are pending, and will be reported as an addendum. UPDATE: ER: Pos PR: Pos HER2: Neg We were at Shands all day yesterday and met with Dr. Spiguel from Shands and found that she thought that it is a nice littel slow grower and that as long as no sentinel node involvement was observed during the lumpectomy, then the Intrabeam administration of high dose radiation on the site of the excised tumor, should be all that is necessary. She uses a 5cm orbit shaped device to zap with radiation during surgery. Of course, all of this is great news, so far. Rad performed a MRI with some contrast for the nodes to identify any other unforeseen hotspots. Waiting this morning for results...It seems that she is a conservationist and I am very hopeful that this will be our eventual course of action. Here is a link regarding her past experience.... On the way to the appointment, I called the Moffit Center in Tampa. Dr. Cox is no longer practicing (Doing mostly research) but I had read that Dr. Kiluk was a good one down there. Paintedlady and Tideknott both seem to like him and I had read other good reviews. The only thing that is a little bothersome is that he cannot see her until next Thursday. So another almost 10 days before he can take a look. I am having Shands send the slides, films and all results down to Moffit and asking them to fax a copy for our folder as well. (Per the “just diagnosed - get prepared” post. (great stuff) Now we just have to wait on the MRI and to meet with Kiluk. Do you think 10 days more is a problem? I know she would like to get this thing out of her.  They seem to think that there is no rush and are fine with a second opinion. I mentioned the perineural invasion and the rad onc replied that they should not even put it on the path report.  (This is congruent with my reseach) BC does not travel via the nerves (unlike prostrate cancer) and it is no big deal.  However, it is rare.  I will be happy when moffit paths re-read the slide and when Dr. Kiluk reccommends the same course of treatment.  However, I am expecting a completely (competing) different treatment plan as it seems that this is common.  Anyway, thanks for all your help and I really appreciate it. Perhaps I should seek another dr. at Moffit who can see her earlier.
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2013 08:40AM tallydiver wrote: Hi Wren, She has already sent it in and is getting tested.  The eval said she had a 10% chance of having it and the tester mentioned that it was pretty high.  Either way, we are going to Moffit on Thursday for a second opinion and will be interested in what they have to say.  She will ask dr. Spiguel when she calls today.  (They played phone tag yesterday)
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2013 02:14PM tallydiver wrote: I am not sure how to feel about this.  Yes I am happy, but wonder about the margins.  Hoping now that the final margins are not close.  Right? She did well with the surgery, but is in a little pain now....(Surgery was last Thursday) DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The patient was taken to the OR and placed in supine position on the OR table. After anesthesia was obtained, the patient was prepped and draped in the standard manner. Timeout was performed to ensure proper operation and patient. Then, 3 mL of isosulfan blue dye were injected in the subareolar position of the right breast. The breast was massaged for approximately 5 minutes of time. At this time, incision was made in the right axilla. Dissection was carried to the pectoral fascia until a total of 3 sentinel nodes were identified. Sentinel node No 1 was 0 blue and had a count of 5093. Sentinel No 2 was 0 blue and had a count of 63 cm. Sentinel node No 3 was 0 blue and had a count 274. The background count was 254, and this came back negative on touch prep analysis. Hemostasis was achieved with cautery. At this point in the operation, the incision was closed with interrupted 3-0 Monocryl suture, followed by a running 4-0 Monocryl sutures. The chest was then brought to the right breast. Incision was made in the lower outer aspect of the right breast. Dissection then proceeded with the use of Metzenbaum scissors around the breast tissue surrounding the septal wire. The breast specimen was labeled short superior, long lateral. Specimen radiograph was performed using the bioptic machine that demonstrated the clip, wire and mass to be within the excised specimen. The specimen was then sent to Pathology for gross evaluation, which demonstrated 2 close margins; there is a close inferior margin as well as a close anterior margin. With this information, new anterior and inferior margins were taken with clips marking the new margins. These additional margins were sent for permanent pathology. Hemostasis was achieved with cautery. The area was then inspected for potential use for intraoperative radiation therapy. A 3.5 cm radiation device was placed within the cavity. Unfortunately, when doing intraoperative ultrasound of the area, there was a close distance between the skin and the radiation probe which was under 5-mm. After consultation with Dr. Correa, the decision was made to not perform intraoperative radiation therapy. Clips were deployed for radiation planning. Incision was closed with interrupted. I hope all is well and that you all have a great week!
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2013 09:17AM tallydiver wrote: Hi Cindy, I am not sure about the details, yet. Those are interesting details that I have not researched, yet.  But I will...and will report back what I find. We will be using Dr. Corea from Moffit and my mom is going down next Tuesday to get inked.  She is already making preparations for the week stay at the free hotel (Not $15) for the week.  I will be sure to include the recent research and question list in discussion with the RO, next week.  Stay tuned!  I know she just wants to get this over so she can do something fun.  (She said that)   I hope you have a great rest of your week and weekend! Kindest Regards, Keith
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2013 06:03PM tallydiver wrote: I am glad to hear that you are responding well to Aromasin.  I have read good things about it and how it mirrors the results of it’s more SE laden cousin, Arimidex.  I would argue that if less side effects are experienced with Aromasin, then why not start with Aromasin.  Perhaps the most conservative approach is to use the drug that has the longest history and if no SEs are experienced, then it would be the recommended approach.  I intend to ask the MO when the time comes. She is still trying to regain energy, but I appreciate the idea of journaling how she feels and how this may help with tracking changes resulting from HT.  She is just getting over a cold now, so hopefully she will get her strength back soon.  I am glad to hear you are still doing well and that all is well.   Kindest Regards, Keith
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver
Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2013 08:21AM tallydiver wrote: Hi Carol, Thanks! We live about 4 hours from Moffit, but the drive is not so bad.  It seems we have three options. 1.  Stay at the $14/day hotel that is supported by Moffit, and spend a week doing three-a-days. 2.  Two weeks of twice per day 3.  6 weeks here in Tallahassee with a Dr. Sharp (Dr. Kiluk spoke highly of him, postop) Tomorrow at 12:30 is the first appointment after surgery with Dr. Kiluk, so hopefully all is well and we get the final path report soon. Hi RMlulu, Thank you.  Yes, it is much better to be on this side of it.  I hope to hear soon about the clear margins and nodes, too.  He had mentioned post-op that nodes were clear...and hopefully the margins are now clear.  I will update you soon as we meet with Dr. Kiluk.  Thank you for your thoughtful posts. I hope all is well with you and your family.
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2013 08:38AM tallydiver wrote: Hi Deanna, She is having done right now, actually.  However, after the initial confidence expressed by Shands, she seems more optimistic.  The MRI results should realized today..I hope.  They seem to indicate that nodal involvement could be observed today, nevertheless, I expect that the sentinel node biopsy will be the determining factor of intrabeam/lumpectomy vs trad rad/masectomy.  If nodal involvement, there was mention of lumpectomy/intrabeam (as a boost) and traditional rad and chemo.  Anyway, we will see what Kiluk/Moffit has to say about this to compare. Kiluk seems to be talented and involved.  I noticed the physician of the year designation, as well. I hope he is worth the wait and expect he will be.  We shall see. I plan to hook her up as soon as she is ready to do it.  I have been printing off different checklists and she has started getting her folders and data in order.  I have talked to her about it and I think she will settle in within a week or so.  It was last Wednesday at 4:30pm that we found out she had cancer, so it is all very new.  Thanks Deanna for caring and responding.  I hope you are doing well.
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2013 02:50PM tallydiver wrote: One other item of interest is that Blue Cross of FL decided to pay for the BRCA testing, so that is a nice $3,500 "present" that accompanied the wonderful visit to Moffit.  I suspect that Myriad's loss in the supreme court to keep the gene testing "under wraps" will have a positive effect on gene testing as others are able to use it to create their own tests.  Have a great week, everyone!
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2013 08:24AM tallydiver wrote: Shands is only two hours, btw.  Moffit is four hours away. She is still experiencing some pain from last Wednesday's lumpectomy.  Did you experience much pain post op?
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver

Posts.Content: tallydiver wrote: Hello everyone.  I am the oldest son and this is what has taken place over the last several days....the initial path report indicates Perineural Invasion is PRESENT.  Is that significant with Breast Cancer? Please help...   Day 1 A  month after my mother had an abnormal mammogram, she finally had a core biopsy and found that she has a tumor that is less than 1cm.  IDC was the only data we have recieved.  Now she is at the beginning of the process and trying to make decisions about surgeons, etc.,   We are thinking about Shands, Gainesville and have found a Dr. Christiana Shaw and Dr. Spiguel  (Both seem to be relatively new docs)  - We are also looking at Moffit in Tampa and even here in Tallahassee...for post surgery care (Oncology) Does anyone have any thoughts regarding next steps.  She is supposed to see Spiguel on Monday.  This is a month now that has gone by, due to a woman's clinic in Orlando taking 3 weeks to perform the biopsy. More about Shaw (blog post related to her credentials) Any advice is much appreciated. She is to see Spiguel because Shaw is tied up for a week.  The scheduler said that Spiguel is very aggressive and not sure why it has taken so long.     Day 2 She is in the whirlwind phase now, but is very strong and accepting.  She is more worried about other girls in our family and wants to do the gene testing to ensure they are not at risk.  I have read that IDC is rarely genetically passed along.  My grandmother had cancer at 45 and died at 55.  Anyway, what she is steamed about is that she had the abnormal Mammo almost a month ago, and scheduling between Shands and the Women's cancer center in Orlando took so long and it was an agonizing almost 4 weeks and then it took nearly a week for her to call at 4:30 Wednesday afternoon to be told that she has cancer.  This happened yesterday afternoon.  She is not sleeping and is trying to decide what to do, but says she doesn't want it to consume her.   I got the line in for her new fax machine that resides in the kitchen.  Tried to get path report today, but since the test did not originate from the local internal med doc, they could not release it.  Anyway, tomorrow should yield results.  Great idea about seeing both, but they work together.  I wonder if they could be objective.  Was thinking about surgery in Gainesville and Oncology in Tallahassee.  Will be sure to bring copies of her film, ultrasound discs hopefully a MRI scan is coming first thing Monday, after the first meeting with the aforementioned Dr. Spiegel.  Thanks again for your words...I am very impressed with the knowledge of this group.  Who knows how many women it helps keep from suffering.  I am very sad that this has happened, but ready to help her fight.   UPDATE: Day 3 Just got the path report faxed over to me.  I like the stage NHS score of 4 on this, but have been reading about the PNI being present and there is an argument related to its importance in BC.  It would seem that nerve infiltration could be a big deal.  Anyway, please comment on the results as we are all still terrified.  I am doing most of the research at this point. A.  Right Breast, core biopsy: - Invasive Ductal Carcinoma of Breast.  See Note - Nottingham Histologic Score: 4 (Grade 1/III)  (Tubule Formation: 1; Nuclear Pleomorphism: 2; Mitosis: 1) - Tumor Size:  10.5 mm in greatest linear dimension on one core. - Lymphovascular Involvement: Not Identified - Perineural Invasion: Present - Focal Ductal Carcinoma in-situ (DCIS) of breast (<1mm), cribiform type, low nuclear grade, without necrosis. - Rare microcalcifications are associated with invasive carcinoma. Note:  Immunohistochemistry for SMMHC demonstrates loss of a SMMHC(+) myoepithelial cell layer in the invasive component, supporting the diagnosis.  Additional studies for ER, PR, and Her2/Neu are pending, and will be reported as an addendum.     Dx 6/5/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery Lumpectomy: Right Radiation Therapy Breast Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2013 11:58AM tallydiver wrote: Update:  There were problems with the MRI yesterday (Technical Difficulty) and she has to go back tomorrow morning for a repeat MRI Bi-Lat with contrast media to light up the nodes.  Getting all folders together and permissions for record release from Shands.  Images and slides... Here is a little video from Dr. Kiluk.  He seems like a competent sounding doc.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2013 12:43PM tallydiver wrote: Just In.  Bi-Rad (MRI) is negative (I will post specifics later)  Additionally, the surgeon called and mentioned that all was well and as expected.  There was mention of BRCA testing and I know that my mother does not meet the criteria, but the doctor mentioned that she would try to get BCBS to pay for it.  Any thoughts on BRCA testing?  It still looks like the lumpectomy, intrabeam option is still.  However, if she is BRCA positive, then masectomy is the route the physician would like to take.  I wonder why the BRCA folks are trying so hard to sell their test.
Posts.Title: Mom - 64 just diagnosed and need your help. tallydiver tallydiver
